ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned about a wide variety of topics regarding approaches to building intelligent machines and moral and ethical considerations to evaluate in the pursuit of building increasingly powerful machines.
I learned many new cognitive science theories as well as new ways to think and write
An absolutely wonderful survey of the intersections of artificial and natural intelligence.
I learned how to analyze AI
I learned how to think critically about AI
Knowledge of how basic AI types work and ways in which the brain works like a computer (and doesn't)

read and discussed many important papers that bridge cognitive science and AI. this class seeks to answer the question of what is AI and is it possible? You will walk out an expert on modern AI and its challenges.
Much better understanding of artificial intelligence and the process of AI and cogsci in the past few years

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a terrific course. I found the readings thought-provoking and the diversity in the background of the students in the seminar was appreciated. All discussions left me with interesting new insights and thoughts.
This class was great. I think its strength lied in how it was a small discussion seminar where we could share our thoughts on these interesting topics with our peers
The professor doesnt really do anything. We just talk and students give presentations.
I wish there was more of a strict format to the actual discussion.

The material was incredibly engaging and Julian did a great job facilitating the seminar. I can't think of anything to improve. Maybe some introductory material on neuroscience for students from a computer science background?
no weaknesses this is an amazing class. Julian is an amazing person and instructor
Reading responses are great ways to foster discussion since people think of points before class

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the virtual setting for this discussion-based seminar worked very well.
The size of the class was perfect to keep me engaged

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any seniors who are interested in the topic of human and artificial intelligence.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone remotely interested in discussing AI and its implications
YES take this class! All the topics are just so interesting, and Julian is wonderful.

Yes! I loved the course. I thought it was very engaging and I enjoyed talking about the intersection between AI and cognitive science. The class was pretty stress free. The readings were interesting and easy to do. The small seminar aspect of the class was nice because you are able to really engage with your peers.

If you want to read interesting papers and have no interaction with the professor then yeah, go for it. That being said, the professor was pretty rude and not helpful in my opinion. Sometimes my  interactions with him made me really turned off about the class in general.
Take it if you have background thinking about some abstract things like representation and how AI works (neural networks). Otherwise, it might be hard to keep up with the other students

100%. Class discussions really made me think and I often left with a different understanding than the one I entered with. I looked forward to chatting with everyone each week. At times it felt more like hanging out with friends than an academic course (though we learned more than in most seminars)
definitely take it if you are interested in AI or computational cognitive science. It would be helpful to have some background in this area but don't need to code or anything.
Absolutely! It is so interesting, the professor is incredible and makes these complex topics clear and interesting, and people are all super engaged

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
